div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond JEDDAH but call at TOR (for Sinai) EL WEDJ and YAMBO as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.

div.head: THE POLICE OF EGYPT
div.p: Perhaps one of the most difficult and serious problems with which the Egyptian Government has to deal is the creation of an efficient police force throughout the country. No adminis ration comes so prominently before the eyes of the public as that of the police, and probably none receives such undeserved and adverse criticism. The European of Cairo and Alexandria is apt to unreasonably demand a service equal to that to which he has been accustomed in the principal cities of his own country. To expect the same attributes here as belong to the police of London, Paris, Berlin, and such towns is quite irrational, and that the shawish should be distinctly inferiror to the European constable is only natural, the materials from which the two are created being so widely different. What do we look for, and moreover find, in the London guardian of the peace? A terroriser of malefactors, a guarantor of security, an autocrat of the traffic, an ally of the weak, a succourer of the helpless, an deviating supporter of justice, and a discriminating judge in cases of emergency. And is it such a man that we can expect to find in the shawish of Egypt, recruited as he of necessity is, from the lowest classes of a none too highly intellectual race? By nature he is indifferent, not infrequently indolent; of discrimination he has none; he is inclined to argue rather than act with promptness; he may frequently be turned from the performance of his duty by bakshish; he is possessed of no initiative; and he is of an extremely excitable temperament. Such is the material out of which the Egyptian policeman must be made and though there are exceptions to the rule, their number is not great.

No one can object to honest, reasonable, and dispassionate criticism- such, indeed, is courted; but only harm can come of intolerant animadversion. When circumstances incline us to decry the manner in which the police service is administered let us moderate our judgement by the consideration of the difficulties under which the administrators labour. A great work has been done by bringing the service to its present state of efficiency, imperfect though that undoubtedly is, and the work is not going backwards, nor is it at a standstill. The need for improvement is fully recognised by the | authorities, who make no attempt to deny it, I but boldly declare it to the public, and they know far better than the public the innumerable shortcomings of the men, which constitute a more effective barrier to progress than any administrative obstacles. In his report to Lord Cromer two years ago Mr. Machell drew attention to the fact that on account of the insufficient sum devoted to the police administration the ranks of the police were of necessity filled by men who, having originally been drawn to the lowest strata, are expected to make the law respected, and to maintain themselves and their families on L.E. 1 per month, Mr. Machell concluded his report as follows:- “With a careful selection of candidates who must be attracted to the Administration by gradually improving the conditions of service, and with a thorough system of instruction of young police officers, moawins, and policemen, coupled with an annual importation of the very best young sub-inspectors we can get from England, I hope in due course to see that improvement which the absence of neceesary funds has delayed for so long." The police budgets of 1905 and 1906 showed a very welcome increase, and special credits have, besides, been devoted to the construction of a police school, new stations, outposts,etc. Improvement has, therefore been made possible and it is gradually being effected, though it may not, as yet, be apparent to all. The work must necessarily be gradual, for certainly no harder task than turning the material which we have described into a capable police force was ever undertaken Rivers may be spanned and confined, desert lands may be converted into highly cultivated regions, towns may be built, bankruptcy may be changed into prosperity, and enslavement replaced by liberty, all in a comparatively short period of time, but the moulding of human character is a slow and tedious process, which can only be achieved by infinite patience.

The shawish can, however, be readily trained to some of the simpler and less responsible duties of a constable, as is evidenced by the excellent manner in which the vehicular traffic of Alexandria is directed. Unfortunately, we cannot say the same of the Cairo police, who, except on special occasions, are altogether heedless of the constant stream of carriages, which rush along pell-mell and ungoverned, though here again the regulation of the traffic over Kasr el Nil bridge at the time when the world of fashion takes its afternoon promenade round Ghezireh shows how much might be done in this direction in other parts of the town. The shortcomings of the native policeman was forcibly impressed upon us at the Denishwai trial. One of the witnesses for the prosecution was the onbashi of police who had accompanied the officers to the village and was afterwards sent to inform the omdeh of the arrival of tho officers. It had been decided by the prosecution not to call upon the man to give evidence at the trial in consequence of the proved untruths which he had told when questioned during the preliminary inquiry. Counsel for the defense, however, asked that he should be called, whereupon Helbawi Bey expressed his willingness, and the onbashi was immediately summoned. The result is known. He was guilty of grow and patent perjury and, in his address to the Court, Helbawi Bey remarked that the only reason why the prosecution had not called for the evidence of the onbashi until requested to do so was that they saw no reason for impressing upon public shortcomings of the Egyptian police. He was not only guilty of neglect of duty by not carrying out the instructions of the officers; he endeavoured to exculpate himself by bearing false witness. Such is the Egyptian policeman. We can but watch the steady progress which is being effected, and in the meantime we must not lay too great a stress upon the imperfections which must be evident for some time to come.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Port Said Terminus.
The Suez Canal Company are considering the plans for a new station at Port Said. A terminus hotel will be annexed.
Mex-les-Bains.
The directors have decided to leave the baths open as long as weather permits, so that halt books of ten tickets can be had for P.T. 5.
Cairo Station
The new platform at Cairo Station for the Upper Egypt line will be begin next year. A new electrical power station is also to be built at Cairo.
Egyptian Quarantine Board
A Pera dispatch of yesterday from the Sanitary Board states that public health at Djeddsh is good. Quarantine in Egypt against Queensland has been abolished.
The Brindisi Hall.
The mail from Brindisi per P. & O. steamer to Port Said is due at that port at three o'clock to-morrow morning, and should be distributed at the G.P.0., Alexandria, at 4.45 p.m.
A Sheikh Dismissed
Darweesh Mustapha, a Sheikh of the Husseiuieh quarter of Cairo, has been dismissed from the Government service for withholding the names of natives who were subject to conscription.
Khedivial Agricultural Society.
The Committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society will meet to-morrow in Cairo to make some arrangements for the Tanta Show which will be held shortly, and to fix the date of the Cairo Show.
Mouled el Shafel.

The Shafel mouled will end to-morrow evening, when the final ceremony will be held at the Shafei morque, Cairo, under the presidence of Sheikb Abmed Ali Mubsin, who has invited a large number of ulemas and notables to attend the ceremony.
San Stefano Casino

The Committee of San Stefano Club have decided to hold a ball with cotillon on Thursday, 27th inst., at 10 p.m., for members only. Members' cards will serve as invitation. Those intending to dine in the restaurant are requested to secure their tables beforehand.
The Kamel Banquet

Owing to the fact that the banquet which is to be given at the Grand Continental Hotel in honour of the return to Cairo of Mustapha Pasha Kamel has been boycotted by the rest of the Nationalist press, the attendance at the banquet will be confined to the Pasha’s own circle of friends.
Pro Macedenia

The subscriptions raised by the Hellenic colony of Alexandria in behalf of the victims of the Bulgarian atrocities at Anchialos have realised thus far £2,400; of this sum 40,000 francs have been sent to Athens to be distributed. The Cairo subscriptions hare produced £1,793; the total for Egypt being £5,186.
Bubonic Plague

During the week ended last Saturday eleven cases of plague were notified throughout Egypt, three of which occurred at Alexandria and eight at Suez. The total number of cases notified since the beginning of the year amounted to 464 against 257 and 854 for the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively.
The Opera Square Incident

Yesterday morning the Cairo Gouvernorat expelled from the country Alexander Kudai and George Arakgi. who were imprisoned by the Hellenic Consulate for 20 days, for attacking the police at the Abdeen caracot, Cairo, a few weeks ago. They arrived yesterday at Alexadris, and will be sent shortly to Greece.
New Terminus for Alexandria

The new terminus of the Egyptian Government Railways at Alexandria will probably be built next year. The site will be on the other side of the existing bridge. It will be fitted with interlocking signalling apparatus. It is to be hoped that the Railway Administration will see its way to build a terminus hotel at the new station, which would be a very greet convenienos.
New Engines for Egypt.

An important new type of locomotive is to be used by the Egyptian Government Railways. It is known as the new class of Atlantic type engine (4.4 2.) and will be employed on the Cairo and Alexandria express trains. One of these locomotives has just arrived and will shortly be tried in order to test its running powers.
The Hama-Aleppo Railway

The Rayak-Hama-Aleppo railway will be taken over by the delegates of the Ottoman Ministry of Public Works. This line, which has a length of 160 kilometres, will be of immense advantage, especially from the commercial point of view, to the country through which it passes, and its construction has been watched with great pleasure by those for where use it is destined.
“The Emancipation of Egypt.”

Some months ago we criticized at great length a work published under the title of “The Emancipation of Egypt.” It is worth noting that this anonymous and able treatise has now been published in French, German and Italian. We hear that the sales of this book have been considerable in Europe, and although we absolutely disagree with the political standpoint of the author, we would in fairness confess that it is written in a most plausible and moderate tone.

div.head: CRETAN HIGH COMMISSIONER
div.p: APPROVAL of the powers Athens, September 24. The representatives of the four Powers have notified the Premier of their approval of the appointment of M. Zaimis as High Commissioner of Crete. (Reuter)

div.head: BOMB FACTORY DISCOVERED.
div.p: FINISH GUARDSMEN ARRESTED.
Stockholm, September 24.
A bomb factory has been discovered here. The chief of the Finnish Red Guard and two others have been arrested. (Reuter)

div.p: AFTER 26 YEAR8 SERVICE.
Constantinople, September 24. Baron de CaliCe who has been the Austrian Ambassador here for the past 26 years has retired. (Reuter)
Constantinople September 24. Baron de Calice, the Austro-Hnngarian Ambassador, has tendered his resignation. (Havas)

div.head: FRENCH ENVOY TO RUSSIA.
div.p: ARRANGING A FRENCH LOAN.
St Petersburg, September 24.
A special French envoy has arrived and is visiting the high officials and the leaders of both parties. It is stated that his visit is for the purpose of arranging a French loan. (R.)

div.head: THE HONG KONG TYPHOON.
div.p: BISHOP HOARB’S BODY RECOVERED. Hong Kong. September 24. Bishop Hoare's body has been recovered. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SULTAN’S ILLNESS.
div.p: Paris, September 24. The ”Temps" which first announced the Sultan's illness learns from an absolutely reliable source that despite the optimistic official statements, the recent consultations showed that his Majesty is suffering from cancer of the kidneys, which is incurablo and is generally fatal within a year. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MISSING MINISTER.
div.p: ELOPED.WITH A GOVERNESS. Paris, September 24. The Cure Delarne, who was supposed to have been murdered near Elaskes, has taken refuge in Brussels, and intends to marry a parochial governess who is accompanying. (Havas)

div.head: THE GEORGIAN TROUBLE.
div.p: New York, September 24. The police of Atlanta state that eight negroes and one negroes are dead. No one else has been injured. No farther trouble is anticipated. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN SOCIALIST CONGRESS
div.p: Manheim, September 21. The Socialist Congress has been opened.

div.head: MOROCCAN FANATICS. EUROPEANS ATTACKED.
div.p: The Tangier correspondent of the “Daily Telegraph” in a depatoh late last Tuesday said that Maelainin, of Shinghit, a Shereet of great prestige in the Adrar country, visited Fez last month, and received honours and valuable presents from the Sultan. He then returned to Shinghit, and camped on Friday at Dar-al-baida with an escort of fifty Adrar negroes, who showed their fanaticism by entering the shop of a French gunsmith, ill treating the native employe, and finally looting the place.

They next ran through the town, seeking Frenchmen, and beating and wounding some Europeans. This caused a great panie, but the local authorities took no effective setion to to resume their journey unmolested.

div.head: THE ASSYH MUTINY.
div.p: TRANSPORT LEAVES PORT SAID.
(From a Correspondent.)
Port Said, Monday.

The affair of the mutinous soldiery on the Turkish troopship has at last been happily settled, as far as Port Said is concerned. The Turkish authorities despatched another vessel, which arrived on Sunday. Five hundred of the troops were transferred to her, leaving some five hundred with the Syrian mutineers on board the Assyr. Both vessels entered the Canal at 1 a m. on Monday. They were preceded by H.M.8. Proserpine and followed by one of the Canal Company’s launches having on board a company of Egyptian troops with several English Officers and the Commandant of the Suez Canal Police. The affair has caused a very great deal of trouble to many of the Egyptian Government Officials as well as to the British Consul.

div.head: THE LABBAN AFFAIR
div.p: OFFICER IN CHARGE DISMISSED.

The Alexandria parquet is continuing its enquiry into the circumstances attending the death of Osman Ahmed at the Labban caracol, which caused such a sensation last Friday evening. The enquiry which the police authorities are instituting with the purpose of establishing the responsibility of the policeman has resulted in the suspension from duty of Yusbashi Mohamed Rffendi Shefik, who was in charge of the earaool at the time. Onbaeshi Mohamed Zaher and Shawish Abdul Aal, who are accused of having struck the deceased, are under arrest.

div.head: “AL GERIDAH.”
div.p: A NEW ARABIC NEWSPAPER.

Ahmed Effendi Loutfy, brother of Omar Bey Lonufy, the well known advocate and the former director of the Khedivial School of Law, is now in Europe busily engaged in studying the latest journalistic methods and printing presses now in vogue. H’s new Arabic newspaper is to represent the views of the Legislative Council, which do not appear to have found sufficient vent in the official journal. What exact position this newspaper will hold amidst the many and various organs of the Nationalist Press, it is at the present moment somewhat difficult to premise, but it is generally believed that it will occupy a moderate place somewhere between “Al Lewa,” which may be taken to represent the opinions of the extreme left wing of the so called Nationalist Party, and “Al Moayad,” which may be considered to embody all the most stable elements of thoughtful native opinion.

It may be remembered that Ahmed Effendi Lonufy is the gentleman whose name will be handed down to posterity as the leading advocate for the defence in the notorious Denishwai case. His abilities have been most fully recognised in the White Papers laid before the Houses of the British Parliament, which deal with the affair. Mr. Findlay, the British Charge d'Affaires, has given his testimony to his forensic pre-eminence, a point upon which opinions may possibly be allowed to differ. We wish our new Arabic contemporary all the success it deserves, for although its new editor is devoid of journalistic experience, that fact may be taken as a high recommendation in some quarters.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Lieutenant J. B. M. Matthews Donaldson, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted extension of leave untit October 10, and Mr. D. Blattner Bey, chief interpreter at Alexandria, has reserved an extension until October 29. Extension of leave until the 24th prox. has been accorded to Major N. W. Haig, Inniskilling Dragoons, upon the recommendation of a medical board. Captain R. C. Wilson, R. A. M. C., has been granted leave of absence from the 1st prox. until the end of that month. Lieutenant W. A. Murray, R.H.A. has returned from leave. Major R. Peroy-Smith, having returned from leave, has resumed command of the Royal Garrison Artillery.

div.head: NEW ROUMANIAN LINE
div.p: CONOTANTZA-ALEXANDRIA.

The representatives of the Serviciul Maratim Roman are arriving at Alexandria about the 7th October in order to make all the necessary arrangements for their new serviee of steamers between Constantza, Constantinople and Alexandria. The first regular sailing will leave Constantza on the 18th October and is due at Alexandria on the 22nd October.

div.head: STHAMRR ASHORE IN SUEZ CANAL
div.p: Suez, Monday.

The P. and 0. steamer Caledonia, homeward bound, ran badly ashore in the Canal last Saturday afternoon in the small lake near Kabret station. The tug Titan was sent to her assistance, but all her efforts to refloat her have been unsuccessful. She is new discharging cargo into lighters and thus it is expected she will come off. The traffic in the Canal is free.

div.head: RAILWAY AMISTRATION.
div.p: INNOVATIONS AND REFORMS.

Among the many innovations, which are being introduced into the State railway system in Egypt is the introduction of the signalling interlocking apparatus, which is gradually being fitted at every necessary point on the main line between Cairo and Alexandria. Many stations, such for instance as Benha, have already been installed with this most necessary part of a modern railway equipment. The work is being pushed on in other stations, and by next year it is hoped that not only will the main line between Alexandria and Cairo be fitted with interlocking signals, but that also the installation will be complete in Upper Egypt as far as Wasta.

Among other improvements now being carried out is the fitting of all the large railway stations with modern restaurants in the latest European style. This work has been entrusted to the International Sleeping Car Company, Limited. A splendid restaurant is at present under construction at the Alexandria terminus.
Considerable improvements are being made in the system of ventilation in the International Sleeping Car Company’s carriages. An up-to-date system is being installed with ice-box apparatus.

Many alterations have just been begun at Tantah station. A new platform for the cotton bales is being constructed there and increased facilities for handling goods and for transhipping merchandise to the Mansourah line are also being provided for at this most important junction in the Delta.
The Egyptian Railway Administration is also providing better facilities for handling cotton at Damaohour station.

A new goods platform has been opened at Gabbari station and a new inward marshalling yard is being made there. Big waggon sheds are to be built in the neighbourhood of Alexandria. The site of these sheds has not yet been decided upon, but they will be either at Max or Gabbari. Here the waggons will be received and repaired. It is out of the question to enlarge the area of the land occupied by the Egyptian Railway Administration in the Boulac quarter of Cairo, as the price of real estate in that quarter of the Capital is quite prohibitive at the present time. A site at Mex or Gabbari will consequently be far more practicable. By making the miner headquarters of the Railway Administration at Egypt’s commercial capital a great deal of the present expense of hauling will be obviated.

The Railway Administration has of late wisely adopted a liberal system of advertising. By this means it is hoped that not only will visitors be attracted to patronise the railways, but that tourists from all parts of the world will be drawn to Egypt and the valley of the Nile daring the Winter season. During the last few months the Railway Administration has distributed from ten to fifteen thousand enormous placards of a most artistic and attractive design throughout all the countries of Europe. Thousands of handy guides to Egypt have also been sent to Europe and at the present time a colossal scheme of advertising Egypt throughout the United States is under the consideration of the Administration.

div.head: THE COMING SEASON-
div.p: GOOD PROSPECTS.

Messrs. Thos. Cook and Sons (Egypt) Limited have received at their Cairo offices satisfactory assurance* from London in regard to the prospects of the coming season. A large number of advanced bookings have already been received and things tend to show that, not withstanding the publicity given by the London Press to the Denishwai affair and similar disquieting incidents, Egypt will still maintain its popularity during the present winter. Messrs. Cook have in fact such confident anticipations of the development of the Egyptian tourist traffic in the immediate future that they are now engaged in building what is destined to be the most gigantic tourist steamer that has ever floated on the bosom of the Nile. It is to he called "Egypt" and will have accommodation for at least one hundred first-class passengers.

The Hamberg and Anglo-American Nile Company have launched the new Nile tourist steamer Nubia and bops to launch the Germanais, which will take the piece of the Mayflower next week. The Germania is of the type of this Company’s well-known river steamer, the Victoria. The Nabia, as already announced, will be confined to the Second Cataract service between Shellal and Wady Halfs. The Company will initiate this season a new bi weekly express service and will employ the Mayflower for this purpose. This service will be of great use to those passengers, who cannot afford the time for the twenty days’ trip. The Company anticipate a good season, and do not seem to have any anxiety that the political situation will in any way have a bad influence.

div.head: EGYPTIACA
div.p: BY JOSEPH OPFORD.
The South Kensington Museum contains a magnificent collection of ancient textiles, but so crowded together at present that their inspection is difficult.
Mr. A. R. Guest has been deciphering the inscriptions upon them. Nine of these texts present names of interest in Egyptian history, after the Arab conquest.
The earliest is that of a Khalil named Marwan, either the father of the celebrated Abd-el-Malik, or the last of the Umaiyad Khalifa. Another is of El Mutadid who was Khalif from 892 to 902 a d.
The third is El Hakim, a Fatimite Khalif of 996 to 1021 a d. The fourth reads “Ali is the Vicar of God, prayers be to them both." This is one of the Fatimite period princes.
Numbers 5 and 6 are of El Mutansir Fatimite Khalif of 1036 to 1095 a.d. Number 7 is of a certain “glorions lord Yumn-ed-Daulah Abu Yumn, or it may be read Nasir-ed-Daulah.
Number 8 refers to El Fa'iz, Fatimite Khalit of a.d. 1149. Whilst the ninth, dates from between a.d. 1293 and 1341 for it relates to the famous Mamluk Sultan of Egypt, Muhammed-ibn-Tala’un.
These inscriptions should be added to the Corpus of lapidary Arabic subscriptions because they all contain additional texts to the titles which, only, are given here.

The same remark applies to a series of eight inscribed vessels shown at an exhibition of Mahommedan art in Paris. The text upon these have been described in the journal of the German Palestine Society by Herr Soberheim. Their inscriptions date from the time of the second Egyptian Mamluk dynasty, and contain the titles of officials Khalifa, a Sultana and Sultan, which are of considerable historical interest.

The last report of the British Museum Egyptian Department, gives special space to an account of the placing in the gallery of the South Wall of the Chapel of the chief pyramid, of the northern group of Pyramids on the island of Meroe in the Sudan. This edifice was built for one of the Candaces, or Queen's, of Ethiopia probably during the first or second century of our era, and its chapels, pylons, and courts were ornamented with sculptured reliefs representing the Queen’s funeral procession and the offering's made at her seulehee.

Her name is not written in the texts and the cartouches provided for it have been left blank. At one end of the wall she is seen seated with her consort, who is also nameless. She wears a hinged garment with cords and tassels, and on her arms are richly ornamented bracelets.

The reliefs on the walls include a table of offerings ; the Hall of Osiris, the judgment scenes, and rows of deities and other figures pouring out libations before the queen. Four bulls also are being led for sacrifice. These sculptures are typical of the best class of such work on the island of Meroe of which, until now, there were no representatives in the British collection.

The Museum has also acquired a splendid rectangular limestone slab from the tomb of Pari the priest of Ptah, and superintendent of the estates of Amen-Ra’s temple at Thebes. He lived under Amenhotep III about B.C. 1450. The King’s throne name is graven on the stone.

The stones of the Mastaba from Sakkara recently sent to Brussels are suffering from their change of climate; it is possible that the surface of the reliefs may gradually disintegrate so as to in time cause serious deterioration. The same difficulty has arisen with many Assyrian reliefs in the British Museum basement rooms and it is one more argument for antiquities being retained in the countries they belong to, whilst casts of them should be liberally offered to foreign collections.

Two important treatises upon Coptie studies have been recently published in Paris by M. Delaporte, both of which also are of value for the history of early Christianity. One of these gives the first edition of two pages of a Coptie manuscript written in the Sabedic Dialect giving part of the book known an "The Shepherd of Hermar," a work which was most popular in the early Christian communities. Some 60 years ago an Ethiopic version was found and edited by M. Abbadie. These two pages of the Coptie one will perhaps suffice to prove whether the Ethiopic text is a translation from the Coptie, or direct from the Greek.

The second work of M. Delaporte gives all the at present known Sahidieo Coptic fragments of the Apocalypse. In addition to those previously published he adds seven new ones, from Paris or London. Probably further search in libraries and Museums would considerably augment the collection for many, Coptie fragmentary manuscripts have been neglected. M. de Ricci procured many for the French Academy, and others are in private collections in England.

Among the De Ricci manuscript is a unique one containing the last chapter of Saint Mark which before the last twelve verses which it is well known are absent in several early codices, inserts a note, "But this also is counted as forming part." A papyrus codex of 30 pages gives the first 8 chapters of St. John. The date of the text is the 6th century.

The last number of the "Recueil de Travaux Epyptiens" edited by M. Maspero, has a varied series of articles on Egyptology. M. Georges Legrain discusses the ancient Egyptian method of editing a genealogy or family tree,"incidentally comparing it with the Hebrew plan as shown in the Bible. The tree (or stem) of Jesse seems to have been quite on the Egyptian system. Herr Von Bissing follows with a note upon the value of the genealogies of private families for Egyptian history and chronology. M. Maspero writes upon the Royal names of the XII dynasty equating the Greek forms as given by Manetho, with their hieroglyphic counterparts. One of the newly published Hibeh papyri mentions a priest darned Manetho who it is quite possible is the famous historian himself.

Ahmed Bey Kamal writes upon two ancient sites in the Delta, the most important of which is Tell-Mokdani in the province of Dakshlieh, which is evidently the Leontopolis of Strabo. M. G. Daressy elits some valuable mathematical calculations preserved upon some wooden tablets in the Cairo Museum. But the ohiet essay is that by Professor Golenisehef; of St. Petersburg, on the papyrus there containing the story of the shipwrecked sailor and its derivatives in the Odyssey and the “Story of Sinbad." The article is a long one and apparently proves the indebtedness of Sinbad to the old Egyptian romance, whilst the position of Homer in the matter is very uncertain.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Major L'Estrange Johnstone, B.B., M.V.O., General Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, is returning from Europe on the 2nd or 3rd October. He has been engaged during a considerable portion of his holidays in studying the latest up to date methods in vogue in the English and Continental railway systems.

One of the most important accessions to the intellectual equipment of the Egyptian State Railways is Mr. Macnamara, who was lately the chief electrical engineer to the world-famed firm of Vickers, Son and Maxim, Limited. Mr. Macnamara has been spending the summer in the United States, where he has been studying the latest American inventions in electric traction and coal conveyers. During his summer leave he has not only visited most of the important railway centres of the United States but he has also paid visits to England, Holland, Belgium, Germany, and France and has in each country carefully and conscientiously inspected every one of the moat recent railway inventions, which can be usefully employed in the Egyptian State railway system.
Mr. Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt) expects to return to Cairo towards the end of October.
Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Summers, who are at the present time staying in Scotland, will be leaving England on October 10 for Egypt.
Dr. A. Kautsky Bey, chief physician to H.H. the Khedive, is staying with his family at the Bean Rivage Hotel, Ramleh.

The many friends of the late Russian Consul at Alexandria, M. Ivanoff,whom departure from Egypt was due to a somewhat unfortuate discovery on the part of the Custom Hones Administration, will be interested to hear that this gentleman is now one of the most active and vigilant members of the secret police of Saint Petersburg. His devotion to the cause of the autocracy is most keen, and he is displaying extraordinary energy and intelligence in his attempts to counteract the revolutionary propaganda in Bussia.

Sheikh Aly Youssef, the Editor and Proprietor of “Al Moayad”, has removed to Sharia Milton near the Nasrieh School, Cairo. His present residence is a magnificent palace, end the rooms are furnished in the most perfect Oriental style. His wife, the Lady Sadat, has brought her bridegroom a considerable fortune inherited from her father, the late Sayed Sadek el Sadat. The Sheikh has had his new palace decorated with exquisite taste, each room having its own characteristic embellishments, while the profusion of the electric illumination is so beautifully arranged that it in no wise detracts from the richness of the Oriental tapestries and furniture. Our excellent confrere does not disdain the latest means of locomotion and has recently invested in a motor car, fitted with all the latest improvements.

div.head: CONTINENTAL HOTEL.
div.p: By kind permisSION of Major C.J.Is Davideon D.S.O. commanding, and Officers, of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliere, the Build will play the following programme of music on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel to- morrow evening from 8 to 11 p.m.

March—Echtes Wiener Blut-C. Komusk. Overture—The White Queen-O. Metra. Welta—Cairene—Marie D. Hornblower. Selection-The Medal end the Maid-S. Jones. Intermezzo-Vielles amours jamais ne wont oubliées [R. Vollstedt.

Bolero Varie—Tornados—C. Le Thiere. Irish Medley-Erin—Dubois. The Yeoman's Wedding Song-Prince Poinatowski. Valae—Queen of the North (Ediaboro).-Bucalossi. American Sketch-A coon’s, dream of the Past- [Myddleton.
Patrol—The Crack Regiment-Moses Tubani. Regimental March—The Khedivial Anthem God Save the King. R. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, le 24 Septembre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a été élevé de 1/8 mercredi passé à 4 1/4 ; vendredi et samedi, il a encore monté de 1/8 par jour, de sorte que nous le trouvons actuellement à 4 1/2 pour cent. C'est une hausse de non moins de 8/8 en quatre jours, déterminée par l'accroissement des demandes d'or pour l’Egypte et notamment pour l'Aœériqee du Nord.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais, que nous avions laissé mardi dernier à 86 5/8 a clûtoré samedi à 86 8/8, soit en baisse de 1/4 de livre. L’Unifiée a également perdu 1/4 à 104 1/2. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 mer credi pour 1e reperdre samedi à 26 8/4. L’A gricole a baissé de 1/8 mercredi à 9 3/4 jour rester à ce prix. La Daïra a perdu 1/8 jeudi pour le rattraper samedi à 16 7/8. La Delta Light a baissé de 1/1 mercredi à 11 1/2 pour regagner 1/8 jeudi et le reperdre le lendemain.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Eygptieu a gagné 1 franc à 778 et la Banque d'Athènes autant k 144.
Ioi, le marché des valeurs s'est montré, ce matin, très réservé, avec tendance k des réalisations, par suite de l'aggravation de la ten. sion monétaire en Occident.

La National Bank a débuté k 26 7/16 pour reculer à 26 5/16 et finir à 26 7/16-1/2. L'Agri- cole s'est tenue à 911/16-2/4. La Cassa d: Sconto a molli à 223, la Banque d'Athèues à 143 et la Banque d’Orient k 13913'. La Banque d’Abyssinie a fléchi à 5 9/16 .
Le Crédit Foncier a été ramené à 772 773 La Daïra s’est raffermie à 16 13/16-7/8 et la Delta Light à 11 8/4-13/16.

L’action Immobilière a rétrogradé k 388 et la part de fondateur à 730-735. L'Enterprise and Development s’est inscrite à 12 9,16. Les Improvements ont été recherchés k 5 6/16. La part de fondateur Agricole do Nil a progressé à 7 8/8 7,16. L’Union Foncière a baissé à 5 15/16. L’action Allotment a é'é traitée à 3 1/4 5/16 et la part de fondateur k 123. Les Automobiles ont avancé k 5 5/8 11/16 et la privilégiée Khedivial Mail k 4 5/8-11/16. Les Jouissances Baux do Caire ont fait 267-268. Les Ciments se sont alourdis à 68.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été ramenés à 17 1/8 3/16 et les Egyptien à 6 3/18. Les Upper Egypt ont perdu environ 1/8 à 4 5/8-11/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont faibli à 8 1/4-5/16. les Markets à 25 sh. et les Sait and Soda à 29 sb. 6. Les Hooker ont été échangés à 015/18.
Nous détachons d’une lettre de Londres, en date du 17 Septembre, le passage suivant:

"La Banque d'Angleterre recueille aujour d’hui les fruits de la précaution qu'elle a eue de fortifier longtemps à l’avance sa situation en prévision d’une exode de l'or ; les fortes saguées pratiquées ces jours derniers pour compte des Etats-Unis et de l’Egypte établirent que les directeurs avaient raison de se montrer excessivement prudents. On dit que tout sera tenté pour empêcher la tension de tourner en orise; ainsi, dès maintenant, on envisage Top- portunité d'un prêt de 3 millions de livres sterling d’or à faire à la Banque d’Angleterre par la Banque de France. Au surplus, même avec l'aggravation des expéditions au-delà de l’Atlantique, ce ne sont que quatre mauvais mois k passer d'ioi an 15 Janvier. Somme tonte, on pent mesurer la durée, sinon l’intensité de ce resserrement monétaire, très grave ! assurément, mais qui trouve un marché pré paré.”

On affirme de bonne source que la nouvelle, donnée par divers journaux, suivant laquelle le conseil d'administration de la Cassa di Soon to se réunirait vers le fin du mois pour délibérer sur l'opportunité d'augmenter le capital de cette Société par une nouvelle émission d'actions est dénuée de tout fondement.

En effet, le directeur général, le président , do conseil d’administration et la plupart des membres de ce conseil étant actuellement en Europe, il n'est guère vraisemblable, ni possible, qu'une pareille décision soit prise en leur absence.

On ajoute, d'ailleurs, que des démarches seraient faites entre temps à Vienne pour obtenir que la prime de 60 fis. primitivement fixée pour les 25,000 actions attribuées au groupe de l'Union Bank soit majorée.
La "Réforme" se dit en mesura d'affirmer que le Comptoir, Financier n’a pas fondé de succursale à Londres, comme l’avait annoncé un autre journal d'Alexandrie.
Pour ce qui est de la distribution d’en dividende de 12% aux actions et de $2 aux parts de fondateur, la "Réforme" ajoute:
"Laseemblée générale ordinaire sera proobainement convoquée, probablement dans la seconds quiezaine d’octobre, et les actionnaires 1 auront alors tous les renseignements de nature à les intéresser.”

Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les actionnaires de la Société d’Eutieprises Immobilières et de Travaux sont informé» que le conseil d’administration a décidé de faire l’appel du Séme quart, sût LR 1 par action Les versements devront être effectués an siège de le Société, 18 rue 81 El Medabegh, au Caire, au plus tard le 15 Octobre prochain. Il est rappelé qu’aux termes de l’article 7 des statuts, toute somme non payée le jour de son exigibilité porte intéret de plefs droit en faveur de la Société, au taux de 9% l’an.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: {Aujourd’hui à midi et demie.)
Il n'y a eu ce matin que fort peu de transactions, mais loi prix sont fermes et l’on constate même une hausse partielle déterminée par le bas niveau atteint.
C’est ainsi qu’on a demandé dès l'ouverture l’Union Foncière à 5 7/8, mais devant l’abstention des détenteurs on est allé jusqu’i 6 livres, prix qui n’a pas non plus trouvé de vendeurs.
Il en est de même de plusieurs autres titres, tels que le Cré lit Foncier Egyptien, les Non govich Hotels, les Splendid Hotels, etc.
Par contre, que'ques valeurs continuent à fléchir: ainsi la Cassa di Sconto tombe à 221 1/1, la Nile Land à 111/9, l’Ordinary Khédivial Mailà 84, la part de fondateur Comptoir à 31 1/2, etc.

Mais le clou de la matinée, o’est sans contre dit la Central Building. Cette action qui avait été émise à £5 et dont il n'avait plus é'é question depuis, s’est tout è coup réveillée avec une hausse prodigieuse. On a débuté ce matin avec une demande active et le coure a été poussé jusqu’à £12. En clôture on est revenu à £10. Il faut d’ailleus convenir que le nombre d'affaires a été restreint

div.head: BRITISH ARMY MANOEUVRES.
div.p: GREAT IRISH VICTORY.

The War Correspondent of the “Daily Telegraph,” writing from Chichester under date of Monday week; gives the following interesting account of Ireland’s victory over the British force-It has been a great day for “Oireland” entirely. The British forces have had a terrible "basting.” Are coming events casting a shadow before? Whether or not the lesson conveyed of what befalls the unready is obvious and sound. In this mimic campaign the invading Irish troops, the “Blue" army, otherwise the Aldershot Army Corps, have easily scored a complete victory over the British forces. And without straining judgment or conscience, the beginning and ending was as would be in actual warfare. Although there were two British Army Corps being mobilised, they were not prepared to take the offensive, so an infantry division, under Colonel Scott-Kerr, with cavalry and guns, was sent in advance to occupy the South Downs, delay the invaders, and protect London at all costs. Behind him, but afar in the rear, were Regulars. Yeomanry, and Volunteers, all, no doubt, figuratively tightening their belts and eager to be led to meet the daring foemen who had scorned the inviolability of our shores Against the single British divisions were three divisions infantry, a cavalry brigade, and artillery. General Sir John French, who commanded the “blue” forces, somewhat equalised matters by sending his three infantry divisions, Major General Hutton commanding—less a brigade of artillery and another of infantry -away to his left to Westbourne and Hambleton to reconnoitre. It was not expected that they would see any British troops in that direction. They did not. The Irish cavalry brigade and the Royal Horse Artillery batteries were dispatched eastward to “Blues" right to Binstead and Reading. From there westward for six miles, were the First. Division troops (General Paget's) and the Second Division (General Bruce Hamilton’s). Britain's “Red" force, so called, though khaki clad, was en trenched upon the Downs, north of Chichester, along the uplands to be seen cast and west of witching Goodwood, from Madehurst to Stoughton. Dawn broke smiling and breezy, and thongh dark and rolling clouds at times filled the sky, yet did the son keep his hononr and the ship-hand, and so throughout the day remained fine. A few drops of rain fell when the ans were going, but there was not enough to moisten the tongue of a road. The wind was too boisterouss for captive ballooning; but the Irish army flew their war kite to a height of over 1,500ft. Reposing cosily and calmly in a hammock beneath the strange box like apparatus lay an officer, taking note of "Reds" dispositions, and talking by wire to his friends below. Poised aloft, like a strange bird, the kite did not seem to move, but lay perfectly still. It would be a difficult object to hit with a shell, and even then little or no injury would befall the apparatus, which even with the cord severed descends safely to the ground.

There was, after all, quite a late start for the opening of hostilities. They were timed for 9 30 a. m., but, of course, by that hour all the troops were in position to begin fighting hammer and tongs. It may be that I did an unconscious injustice to others when I said yesterday the astute Japanese had sent three officers to watch these manoeuvres. But the Germans are not a whit behind them in that respect, and that is not taking count of visitors who may be in mufti. In the course of a chat I had to-day with an attache of a neighbour nation, he expressed his regret that more of his military countrymen did not cross to study these operations. They were shy of visiting without an invitation, and he hoped to see many of them next year. The silly thing was that on the Continent they persisted in thinking England had no army, whereas, though the force was small, it was a unique soldiery, far better equipped and smarter handled than any to be seen elsewhere in Europe. And he spoke neither through his cheek nor through his hat, but straightforwardly, as a soldier and a gentleman. The capacity to bear and to wield arms is not exhausted in the islands of the tea.

What a charming region is this south country! Velvety downs, wide fields, stately woods, and parks whose giant trees and long avenues remind one of the Forest of Compiegne. It it a country with a history to every hill, fur tumuli and Roman encampments abound in all directions. What a great struggle the early Britons most have made, for here abouts are camps by the score, and Chichester is but a mile and a half from a navigable waterway. A little after nine a.m. I found the "Blue" cavalry brigade, the 5th Lancars, the 8th Hussars, and a brigade of the Royal Horse Artillery, under Colonel Phipps-Hornby, lying in wait a little to the north of Binstead, seven miles east of Chichester. They were in a "dip,” surrounded by timber, near London, so that you almost tumbled upon them before seeing guns or troopers. Conninngly they detached a Royal Horse Artillery battery and a squadron of Lancers to ride straight northward, whilst the remainder galloped off to the north-east, towards Madehurst and the extreme left of their enemy's position upon the Downs. Their ultimate object was to effort a lodgment upon the high ground upon “Red’s” left and rear by Bignor Hill, Burton Down, and Upwaltham Hill. A little way beyond Slindon were a few mounted “Red” scouts, further north there were more, whilst holding Halnaker, on Windmill Hill, and other dominant points were infantry end artillery. Colonel Scott Kerr, with wonted prescience,had made the best possible use of the ground. Not knowing where his enemy would attack, he had sent forward outlying detachments to hold various positions and force the “Blues" to dicclose their strength end purpose. Behind he had a second line of defence along the Ridgeway Down, which afforded him a serviceable means of intercommunication across his whole front. He had a battery upon Windmill Hill, and another to the west, whilst upon the ridge road, or near, there was disposed his main artillery, field guns, howitzers, and heavy gnns—the big 6O pounders. But I fancy the “Red” leader thought the blow to be driven home would fall mainly upon his right, some where near Goodwood.

When “Blue’s” cavalry, at 9.30 a.m., set spurs to their horses, other gone galloped for- , ward with the troopers. They plongeJ by bucky reads or lanes, screened from observation, and meeting with little or no opposition. The few “Red" scouts were brushed aside, and "Bine’s" cavalry held straight upon their mission. Oh, for a battalion of riflemen, to. I have held them op and scattered them to the winds! But despite perfect signallers and field telegraph wires, there, was just the usual incident of mischance, which has won and wrecked kingdoms and empires as well as mere men and women. Nature always fights on the side of the defence, but it follows that if there be neglect by the children of the land, an enemy may profit by nature’s advantages. What a wellmarked countryside is this South land—a fat district, embroidered lavishly with bushes, woods, and noble parks. The bold South Downs and sentinel foot-hills look upon the expanse of the glinting, dancing Channel waters. The infantry of the first “Blue” division, General Paget’s, advance northward by Aldingbourne towards Sethurst Park, and westward as far as the Trundle by Goodwood. Moving in the low gronnd, they quickly came into contact with “Red’s” infantry extended south of Windmill Hill. A few more “Red” cavalry would have helped to stay and control the advance of the invading infantry. Although in a sense it was not a cavalry country, yet does skill convert to its own use the most unlikely situations. So General French, by his bold and resolute handling of that arm, made the occasion and the day an ideal one for getting splendid results from his troopers and Royal Horse Artillery. For over two hours the contending infantry fought around Halnaker Hill,a billowy upland, surmounted by a picturesque, mined windmill. There was a mournful suggestion of the mighty gibbet about the uncanny thing. The dilapidated wheel hung with the skeletons of two centuries of gone-by millers. The few Grenadiers who he'd Halnaker had a red flag, which in indicated that some two companies of men were manning the old Roman earth wall and the rained mill. Their battery blazed way at a section of the infantry and the squadron of Lancers who stopped to engage their attention, whilst their comrades robde unseen to the north. Paget brought a battery to bear upon Windmill Hill from the south, by Boxgrove, and the squadron of Farriers with the battery opened upon it from the east. Rifla fire rose and fell at times, shrieking in fall chorus in the woods. But parsimony stultifies in many modes the soldiers' efforts to learn in field manoeuvres the lesson of war. In France there is no stinting of ammunition for cannon or small arms, but it is otherwise with guns, and as ammunition has to be carefully husbanded you have to imagine at times that continuous rifle and cannon firing is going forward.

By 10.50 a.m., if not earlier, the Blue or Irish cavalry, having rushed upon the British left, seized Selhurst Park, and beyond the ground Buxton Down, theoretically, if not practically. This lost the day to the "Red” leader, and had he been anxious to save his guns and division he would have withdrawn his left and fallen back, for, remember, in front he war being assaulted by two full divisions of infantry and a brigade, and not even his hastily constructed entrenchments could have saved him. It could and would have been a sauve qui pent had “Blue” forged the fighting, but it was the British leader's duty to die hard, and interpose himself between the enemy and the road to London. “Blue’s” cavalry were so lodged and had so struck home, that “Red's” position grew hourly worse. But woods and bills, hearths and homes, England — our England—were worth dying for than living to be dispossessed of them. Events hastened, sod before eleven a.m. Windmill had to be evacuated, the "Reds” retiring upon the Down Ridge road. From eleven a.m. until noon, and later, the conflict surged to and fro, for “Blues” infantry were beginning to press upon Goodwood. Guns were booming in all directions, and over a front of seven miles there rose and fell the rattle of battle in full roar. The "Reds” were clinging to Silhurst, busily fighting with facet turned to east and west. About 12.40 p.m. they began moving off their howitzer and field batteries to the west, towards Goodwood. Their heavy guns were still further to the west than the racecourse. Silently through the woods from Molcomb, over a mile south, almost without opposition, had penetrated the Leinster Regiment, General Alderson’s brigade of Paget’s division. They reached the ridgeway, and spread along it to the west, bagging “Reds” scouts. The British artillery were in a tight place, and the Irish were within an ace of bagging two batteries of “Red’s” field guns and ditto of his howitzers But the gunners, warned, slipped away over hill and due to the north, and still the battle raged. Infantry of the “Red” force were caught between the upper millstone of cavalry and guns and the nether of swarming infantry Those that were not killed were made prisoners. Paget's force on his immediate left broke in upon the racecourses at Goodwood. Alas, poor British force its left was lopped off and gone, and the centre was broken, and their strength wasted. What was happening farther West ward was of snall moment. The day was lost, a famous victory without a Blenheim tinge. About 1.30 p.m. up went the signal balloons that the fight wss over for the day. Back to their camps marched the troops ready to renew the contest on the morrow.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE SALT MONOPOLY.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—Cannot something be done to improve the quality of the salt usually purveyed which is more tasteless than any I have ever used in England or upon the Continent? Would it be too much to ask the authorities that they should test its quality and insist upon its being up to a certain standard of strength? It was imagined at the time when the price was reduced last year that the too generous concession granted by the Government, whereby it deprived itself of working its own salines for the next twenty years, would be an inducement to the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company to provide the public with the best quality possible. Unfortunately our expectations have not been realised, and I can only hope that the Government, now that its attention has been drawn to the fact, will institute a more rigorous supervision and insist on its quality being raised. Truly Yours, X. Y. Z.
Cairo, 23rd September.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POSTAGE.
div.p: To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.” Sir,—No one more than myself is more willing to acknowledge the enormous progress which the Egyptian Postal Administration has made under the guidance of our admirable Postmaster-General, Saba Pasha. However, I should like to make a few suggestions on this Administration as I am sure they will be taken in good part by bis Excellence. For example, the letter postage from England is four farthings for one half ounce and less. But from Egypt to England it is five milliemes or five farthings, leaving, therefore, an excess charge of one farthing per half ounce as against Egypt. At first sight that may appear very small, but when one comes to one ounce it is already one half-penny, two ounces one penny, and so forth. The percentage must be enormous and the discrimination against this country must therefore be very great. Why should this be the case? It was understood in England when the rate was reduced that it would be reciprocal, and this I believe to be the case throughout the Empire, wherever penny postage has been introduced. The argument that the small piastre consisting of five milliemes is the unit of coinage might possibly be brought forward by some in search of an excuse. But this will hardly hold water when we remember that the postage in Cairo is three milliemes.—I am, Sir, Yours obediently.
Enquirer.
Cairo, September 23.

div.head: REVELRY BY NIGHT.
div.p: To the Editor op the "Egyptian Gazette.” Sir,—I happen to live in one of the most select quarters of Cairo; in fact in the smartest part of Sharia Kasr el-Nil. I have selected my flat there because I thought that as that district of the Capital of Egypt was inhabited by Anglo-Egyptian officials and equally respectable persons, I should therefore have some guarantee of the repose which I requite from my studious labours. Unfortunately I appear to have been baulked of my expectation, for last night, (Friday, September 22nd) the flat over my head, which is occupied by a British Official, was the theatre of a most terrific orgy. Only a few day ago I read the following paragraph in a French newspaper published here, entitled “Un pen ie calme” :—

Sans vouloir faire trap directement allusion a des evenements encore presents a toes les esprits pous pensons qu’il est de notre devoir de reclamer de quelques fonetionnaires ou personnalites representant le Regime pas cupation une reserve qu’ils ne semblent pas disposesak observer surtout apres minuit.

Das faits profondement regrettables se soot produits ces derniers temps dans divers establisments publ'os du Caire et d’Alexandria au idjit de* quels nousavots r. fu de nombre uses pro testa* i nr. Nona n'exagdrons rien et savons ienir oompte des oonslqnenoes de ‘la oba- enr oommunioative des banquets ” ; mais il ist des limites qne ne doivent franohir ni lee lommea da monde, ni snrtoat des fonotion- laires—rslativement tits bants—qui oct eu i oertsin moment la respousabilitd du boo irire dans one grande villa de I’Bgypte.
“C’est lesonoidu respect du Regimeaotnel it des be mines dminent* qui la represented it Ie dirigeot qni nous inspire ees qoe'qnes ignes qni oonstitneront, eipdrons-le, an ever- isaement suffisant."

When I read the above I thought that it had been only inspired by “Little Englander" sentiments, but judging from the inexpressible uproar last night, this is not the ease. Surely instructions might be given from the various Ministries that such rowdyism is most unseemly and only calculated to bring contempt upon the British name. I much regret having to make snob a suggestion, but I can think of no other way of bringing this scandalous state of things to the notice of the authorities, and of checking the thoughtless indifference to the comfort of others, which so frequenntly marks the conduct of those who should be the first to set an example. I am, Sir, truly yours,
"Vox Clamantis in Deserto."
Sharia Kasr el Nil, Cairo, September 23.
